message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fixed, split S2 heart sound suggests a congenital heart defect, and among the options, only failed formation of the septum secundum can cause a condition called atrial septal defect (ASD) which can result in the blue discoloration of the hands and feet. Lithium use by the mother during the first trimester increases the risk of Ebstein's anomaly. Failure of the ductus arteriosus to regress causes a patent ductus arteriosus, and failure of the aorticopulmonary septum to spiral leads to transposition of the great vessels.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of turning blue on crying, fixed split S2 heart sound, and absence of S3 or S4 suggests a diagnosis of atrial septal defect (ASD). Among the options, failed formation of the septum secundum is the only one related to ASD. Lithium use by the mother during the first trimester is associated with Ebstein anomaly, not ASD. Failure of the ductus arteriosus to regress is associated with patent ductus arteriosus, and failure of the aorticopulmonary septum to spiral is associated with transposition of the great arteries.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's presentation is suggestive of a cyanotic heart defect, and the fixed, split S2 heart sound suggests an atrial septal defect. Option D, failed formation of the septum secundum, is the cause of an atrial septal defect. Lithium use by the mother during the first trimester is associated with Ebstein's anomaly, and failure of the ductus arteriosus to regress or failure of the aorticopulmonary septum to spiral are causes of patent ductus arteriosus and transposition of the great vessels, respectively.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest that there is a right-to-left shunt, which causes cyanosis. The fixed, split S2 heart sound, and lack of respiratory distress suggest that the cause is a congenital heart defect. Among the options, only failed formation of the septum secundum results in an atrial septal defect, which can cause a right-to-left shunt.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest a patent foramen ovale (PFO), which is a type of atrial septal defect. The failed formation of the septum secundum is the cause of the PFO. The other options are not related to PFO or the presentation described. Lithium use during the first trimester can cause Ebstein's anomaly, which is not consistent with the patient’s symptoms. Failure of the ductus arteriosus to regress causes a patent ductus arteriosus. The failure of the aorticopulmonary septum to spiral causes transposition of the great vessels.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the presentation suggests a possible underlying congenital heart defect, specifically an atrial septal defect. The fixed, split S2 heart sound without the presence of an S3 or S4 is typical of this defect. Among the options, only failed formation of the septum secundum is related to this defect, as it is a necessary component of the atrial septum. The other options are not related to this specific defect.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of cyanosis and a fixed, split S2 heart sound, suggesting a congenital heart defect. Among the options, only failed formation of the septum secundum is a cause of a congenital heart defect with these symptoms. Lithium use during the first trimester can cause Ebstein's anomaly, which is a different cause of congenital heart disease. Failure of the ductus arteriosus to regress is associated with a continuous murmur, while failure of the aorticopulmonary septum to spiral is associated with transposition of the great vessels.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a fixed, split S2 heart sound, which suggests an atrial septal defect, meaning the septum secundum failed to form properly. The other options refer to other cardiac defects. Lithium use during the first trimester can cause Ebstein’s anomaly, failure of the ductus arteriosus to regress causes patent ductus arteriosus, and failure of the aorticopulmonary septum to spiral causes transposition of the great arteries.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of cyanosis and fixed split S2 heart sound suggest an atrial septal defect. Among the options, the only one related to a septum defect is failed formation of the septum secundum. Lithium use by the mother during the first trimester is more likely to cause Ebstein anomaly. Failure of the ductus arteriosus to regress will lead to a patent ductus arteriosus. Failure of the aorticopulmonary septum to spiral will lead to a transposition of the great arteries.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms (turning blue) indicate a possible congenital heart defect. Among the options, only failed formation of the septum secundum can cause a cyanotic heart defect (such as atrial septal defect). Lithium use by the mother during the first trimester can cause Ebstein's anomaly, but the symptoms do not fit. Failure of the ductus arteriosus to regress and failure of the aorticopulmonary septum to spiral can lead to different heart defects but not cyanotic ones.
